column1: Will the People's Republic of China's (PRC's) military expenditure as a percentage of GDP be greater in 2021 than it was in 2019?
column6: ['Foreign Policy', 'Security and Conflict']
I'm very, very glad to see other people disagreeing with the crowd's degree of confidence on this one. Staying halfway between the agnostic 50% and the 96% of the crowd.
Previous rational still stands - https://www.gjopen.com/comments/1345789

Genuinely baffled at the crowds confidence on this one. I think it's more likely than not, but certainly not a 98% chance, especially when we're forecasting so much in the dark. Give the article I cited at https://www.gjopen.com/comments/1331996 it seems more than possible this could go the other way as GDP has been more resilient than expected, it's pretty late in the game, so a change now is almost meaningless, but I'm not comfortable giving the overall odds more than a 2-1 chance.

https://www.fxstreet.com/news/chinas-gdp-forecast-raised-for-q4-2021-and-2022-jp-morgan-202112150846 adjusted GDP forecast for CHina by JP Morgan. Readjusting my prediction to 48%. This one is going to be close.

Initial guess, just looking at SIPRI-numbers for the past 20 years: Mean 1,8% of GDP, minimum 1,7% max 2,0%. 2019 was 1,7%. Last time it was above 1.7% was in 2016, when it was 1.8%. Before I do try to find any other info my inital guess is it most likely to be similar to the last few years.

In the face of weakening GDP growth will the CCP curtail military spending? I think not, or at least not that much. I've been on the low side (wrong side it seems) of the crowd so far. We always knew that the Chinese economy would hit a speed bump one day. Still, Evergrande surprised me.
Increasingly looking like China's GDP growth will dampen in Q4

SHANGHAI, Sept 28 (Reuters) - China's power supply crunch, that has shut factories across the country, may pose a much bigger threat to the economy than the debt crisis at Evergrande Group (3333.HK), prompting investors to shun industries vulnerable to power shortages such as steelmaking and construction.
Increasing again on the potential impacts of Evergrande and supply line disruptions (note: there is an inverse relationship between this question and GDP grow).

- I'm not seeing where the 1.8886% comes from; when I look at the spreadsheet I get 1.7278% - Looks like the crowd is being overconfident, but maybe not that much - Disappointing that this question depends more on GDP growth than on military expenditure growth. - GDP growth might be affected by the Evergrande affair. - I'm still anchoring a fair bit on the crowd

If China's military spending meets the forecast of 6.8% growth in 2021, any GDP growth greater than 8.15% will result in a "no" outcome. Given the uncertainty of estimates for both military spending and GDP forecasts, this is difficult to predict. However, the most recent data showing stronger than expected Chinese GDP growth in the first half of 2021 suggests that the crowd is overconfident here. Especially given that military share of GDP did not increase in the three years before the pandemic.

"While policy makers remain comfortably on pace to hit their full-year growth domestic product target of at least 6%—first half GDP growth was 12.7% year over year—further deterioration in these two sectors [ Real estate investment and construction] could change the calculus for leaders in Beijing." https://www.wsj.com/articles/chinas-economic-recovery-is-looking-gloomier-11631683862?mod=article_inline

Found this little tidbit: "China stands out as the only major spender in the world not to increase its military burden in 2020 despite increasing its military expenditure, because of its positive GDP growth last year,’ said Dr Nan Tian, SIPRI Senior Researcher. ‘The ongoing growth in Chinese spending is due in part to the country’s long-term military modernization and expansion plans, in line with a stated desire to catch up with other leading military powers." https://sipri.org/media/press-release/2021/world-military-spending-rises-almost-2-trillion-2020
Hedging because of uncertainty with delta everywhere

There goes the economy: With one of the world’s highest rates of pork consumption, China is normally home to about half of global pig stocks. But its porcine population has been severely affected by a swine fever panzootic (the animal equivalent of a pandemic) that began in 2018 and has threatened herds in many countries. It has wrought havoc in the supply of China’s staple meat, creating wild swings in the prices of pork and feed grains. Officials say that in 2019 it resulted in the loss of between one-fifth and one-third of the country’s pigs from disease or culling. That year swine fever cost the industry between $50bn and $120bn, according to the Asian Development Bank. In 2020 stocks recovered swiftly. But by late last year infections began to rise again. https://www.economist.com/china/2021/08/28/african-swine-fever-is-spreading-rapidly-in-china-again

Pushing back up slightly given that the SIPRI estimate for 2019 is reduced in the spreadsheet. This increases the odds of resolving to yes by reducing the bar to beat.

As stated in Janes China’s 2021 defence budget is the largest growth since 2019, whereas 2020 was the lowest for many years. This is in line with China’s policy of aligning their military spending allocations to the country’s economic growth (GDP). This has been about 1.889% of GDP in recent years. Growth was severely affected by the Covid pandemic that produced a growth rate of 2.27% and therefore limited their military budget for that year. Estimates for 2021 growth are 8.4% as China’s economy boosts from the pandemic turndown. China has increased its military budget 6.8% in 2021 but this in the light of the extensive growth rate of this year. In 2019 their defence budget was increased by 7.5% with a lower GDP growth of 5.82%. Therefore, given a fairly modest increase 6.8% of military spending in 2021 compared to the economic growth of the country (estimated 8.4%), the percentage of GDP planned for military spending could perhaps be equal or less than 2019.

It seems whatever happens with the economy military goes up about 7%, last year the economy went down 2%, GDP is expected this year to be about 9% so it 2019 military rate x 1.07/1.02 x 1.07/1.09 which is up
100%. The GDP comparison will be a substantially higher percentage. It will be lost to three main issues: secret operations, corruption, and higher labor costs.

I have revised my initial prediction in order to curb my natural exuberance in ‘going polar’ and taken note of the various types of advice to improve the predictive process and increase flexibility. China has increased its budget for 2021 but appears to be acting with restraint in line with its GDP growth and maintained a single digit growth.
Dialing down a bit, not because I think I'm wrong but because I'm now trying to avoid extremeizing my forecasts relative to the crowd, just in case I'm wrong.

2021 gdp forecast is 16.64 Trillion USD vs 14.34 Trillion in 2019 (https://www.statista.com/statistics/263770/gross-domestic-product-gdp-of-china/) Official 2021 Military budget is 209.2 Bn USD while SIPRI says 240 Bn USD in 2019 (https://chinapower.csis.org/military-spending/#:~:text=In%20March%202021%2C%20China%20announced,183.5%20billion)%20spent%20in%202020.) That means official forecast is ~1.26% of GDP, SIPRI has 1.7% for 2019, which I thought seemed really far off until I saw the CSIS breakdown (https://www.csis.org/analysis/understanding-chinas-2021-defense-budget) which says "SIPRI estimated that Chinese defense-related expenditure actually reached $240 billion in 2019—nearly 40 percent higher than the official budget ($183.5 billion)." So the 209.2 could really be 292.9 BN USD, meaning the real number could be ~1.76% of GDP. It seems that 40% extra is pretty consistent in SIPRI's estimations. So, we've got 2 variables... how much above the official numbers will SIPRI state actual spending to be?... and what will actual GDP growth be?... For the statement to hold true if we assume GDP estimates track SIPRI would need to believe real numbers are 35% or more above reported... which seems likely given past reports Or, GDP numbers could go higher than forecast, which also seems possible given the variability of forecasts over the last few months. I'm reasonably confident they won't spend less on the military so am essentially ruling that out. All said, it seems more likely than not but will need to re-evaluate as gdp estimates are revised. I'll start with 64% and update from there...

If the SIPRI's number is around official military expenditure growth of 6.8%, then the % of GDP will be less than 2019. The problem is it is practically never equal to official numbers, with relatively wide spread. My crude estimate is 67% probability for the SIPRI % of GDP in 2021 to be less than in 2019. I better correct my estimate as I put it too low.

+25. 2020 came in at 1.7498 compared to 1.7278 in 2019. The latest release shows that SIPRI switched all their numbers to the new methodology, so this confirmed we will be comparing like to like, which was one reason I was at 45% instead of 50% because I initially believed this might be a tossup.
SIPRI data tells us that it doesn't often go above 1.7%, ditto Greyowlsova and Yassenoff's thinking on GDP growth and military budget growth.

Two issues to balance here. The Chinese economy is growing and projected to grow at an aggressive rate. At the same time, their military expenditures have been growing aggressively as well, in part to expanding their ability to project military power, as well as to be military competitive with the United States. Can military expenditures outpace economic growth in China in 2021? Possibly, but not for sure.

The average military expenditure as % of GDP for the period of 2005 to 2019 was 1.91%. The 2019 number of 1.89% was below this average. So on this basis alone the 2021 expenditure are likely to be above 1.89% and to revert to the mean of 1.91%. However GDP growth in 2021 could be higher than in 2019 as the Chinese economy recovers from the pandemic. The risk to GDP growth is to the upside rather than downside from what we know now. I have done rough calculations based on SIRPI numbers to determine how sensitive military expenditures as a share of GDP to a 1% change in GDP. The ratio of 5 to 1, i.e. a 1% increase in GDP will reduce military expenditure as a % of GDP by 0.2%, keeping the USD number of military expenditures constant. In 2019 GDP growth was 6% and if this year it will be 7% then assuming mean reversion to 1.91% of military spending to GDP, we need to adjust it lower by 0.2% to 1.89%. This is also assuming that China will stick to the same logic of military spending as they did in previous years and will not decide to boost or reduce for some geopolitical or domestic reasons. Therefore the answer then narrows down to: will China's GDP growth is going to be above or below 7% in 2021? This is a close call at this stage. I think that the GDP growth will print the growth rate between 6 and 7% in 2021. Thus military spending should be between 1.89% and 1.91%, so probably higher in 2021 than in 2019.

I would imagine we don't really know the current numbers in the first place. We probably could not agree on how to measure it even if we had all the numbers because some activity would be considered "military" by some people, but not by others. But I would assume that given the economy is growing, everything will grow. But not necessarily by % of GDP. Also the % of funds available to the national government vs private might change. If we only measure government "military" expenditures we might get a very different number than if we do not. Basically my prediction is that I don't know. -- I do see that SIPRI lists it as 1.9% of GDP for all recent years with a slight declining tendency. 'very slight. It's basically unchanged by those numbers. But we can choose only YES or NO, so I'll give NO a slight edge. -- I'm not considering the new 5year plan because I don't know th influence of that. My basic assumption is that whatever the number is, it probably won't change much.

The IMF projects Chinese GDP growth of c.8.1% in 2021 (https://www.imf.org/en/Countries/CHN). From the SIPRI spreadsheet, using the constant USD figures and calculating the increase on previous year, military spending increases only exceeds this in one of the last 10 years (a fair cut off, I think, after the defence boom '90s) and the average was 6.4%. However, we also need to factor in that China's 2020 GDP growth in real terms was estimated at only 1.9%. Assuming that defence spending continued with no significant hiccup from COVID (lower activity levels are possibly a saving?) and grew at 5%, the economy would be at 101.9% in 2020 but defence spending would be at 105%. Then in 2021, economy would be at 110.15%, but defence spending would be at 110.25% of 2019 levels (i.e. just higher in relative terms). This implies that with these assumptions, the figure *will* increase if defence spending growth continues at 5% through 2021. But unless I'm missing something (quite possible!) it's very very close. I think the ongoing geopolitical competition with the US, irrespective of the Biden presidency, will push Chinese defence spending up, if anything. So that nudges my upwards a bit.

China Power website has a good graph of trends of both military expenditure and GDP. They are projection a significant drop in GDP this year. Military expenditures are projected to remain about flat, therefore the question isn't if military expenditures are going to exceed GDP, but how much will GDP be constrained. My hesitancy is will China constrain their military expenditures to accomodate a GDP significant crash. If not, it will be significantly higher.

First forecast, gut feeling + 5 minutes on Google. High probability on yes that Chinese military spending will be higher in 2021 than 2019. Under normal circumstances, normal inflation would dictate an increase, however with COVID I see China increasing military spending as a result of using national resources (the military) in helping to fight COVID.

I think this question will end up depending more on SIPRI's methodology than China's actual military spending. The numbers are too constant as a percent of GDP, and it looks like SIPRI uses China's numbers but adds estimates of military spending outside of China's official numbers. It seems like these might be based on other categories of Chinese spending, like R&D, based on what the linked report says, which would help explain how the numbers remain so consistent relative to GDP. To complicate matters further, SIPRI appears to have recently changed its methodology and the new estimates appear lower than the old ones. I've requested a clarification on how this resolves if SIPRI changes its methodology and either does or doesn't update the 2019 numbers.

I started knowing nothing, nada, zip. Thanks to the efforts of over half-dozen thinkers and researchers I now think I know something and will alter my forecast. The answer to this question is only as good as the data provided, which many have pointed out is difficult to find. While spending will most likely increase, so will the GDP on which the reported number is based. Given that these data are not audited, the status quo reported numbers would appear best to not raise alarm elsewhere. Thus I will scale my forecast to anticipate the reported percentage, which is likely to be similar to recent numbers to avoid concern by others.

@keith-huggins this would seem to seal it : China is not alone in excluding elements of defense-related spending from its official defense budget. India’s paramilitary forces, which make up the Central Armed Police Forces, fall under the Ministry of Home Affairs, not the Ministry of Defense. India is also not forthcoming about space and nuclear weapons expenditures. The United States funds its nuclear weapons through the Department of Energy and does not include these details in its defense budget. However, the US government maintains a high level of budgetary transparency, which enables analysts to readily account for discrepancies From you previously: https://chinapower.csis.org/military-spending/

Chinese military spending does appear to be consistent and tied their growth in GDP that seems to settle around between 1.88% and 2.1% between 1999 and 2019. Apart from January 2020 the height of their pandemic crisis the economy has recovered with an expected 8.1/2 % growth in 2021. Therefore, China can increase its military budget (as it has) and still keep within its traditional 1.9% average of its GDP. However, given the lack of transparency, it is probably impossible to ascertain a true figure, but considering the track record, a no change in the % of GDP spent on the military is envisioned.

Base rate Using the Excel sheet’s data from 1989 to 2019, 46.66667% of transitions from one year to the next were accompanied by an increase of military spending as a percentage of GDP. For 2000 to 2019 this was 52.6316%. For 2005 to 2019 this was 57.1429%. For 2010 to 2019 this was 66.6667%.

Just eyeballing. China's spending on defense rises virtually every year, and 2020's increase was unusual in that it was much smaller than typical.

Looking at the past 20 years of data, China's military spending has been nearly constant as a percentage of GDP. Spending increases have kept up with GDP, but not exceeded it. Rapid GDP growth has allowed equally rapid increases in military spending.
The absolute amount will surely be larger. The pct of GDP may not get clear for a while yet. Odds are this will be a Yes, but I don't have any actual evidence for this yet. Stay tuned.
Without any data or any understanding of the nuances it would appear that this figure will be higher going forward. I welcome feedback.
